misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the input will always be a valid grade within 0–100, so the program doesn’t need to handle values outside that range.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The problem statement specifies grades are 0–100. If the user enters an out-of-range number (e.g., 105 or -3), this code will still assign a letter grade (105 -> A, -3 -> F) even though such inputs are invalid per the specification. While not required in many CS1 settings unless explicitly stated, it reflects an implicit assumption about inputs rather than explicit enforcement.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Potential wrong/undefined output for out-of-spec inputs (no error, but produces an unintended letter grade).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No misconception detected (correct conditional range mapping)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that checking grade thresholds from highest to lowest (>=90, else if >=80, etc.) will correctly map any 0–100 numeric grade to the intended letter grade.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap here. In Java, an if/else-if chain is evaluated top-down and only the first true condition executes, which correctly implements the provided grading scale when ordered from highest threshold to lowest.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error; produces correct output for all grades in 0–100 (and still gives a reasonable result for out-of-range values, though input validation was not required).
